Question Text: Which of the following terms describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and is delivered to multiple devices on the LAN? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Multicast address
b. Broadcast address
c. Unicast address
d. IP address
e. MAC address
LLM Explanation: Multicast and broadcast addresses are the two types of Ethernet addresses that can send a single frame to be delivered to multiple devices on a LAN. A multicast address allows a frame to be sent to a specific group of devices, while a broadcast address sends the frame to all devices on the LAN. Unicast addresses are used for sending a frame to a single specific device. IP address refers to the network layer addressing, not the Ethernet (data link layer) addressing. MAC address is a general term for the Ethernet address, which includes unicast, multicast, and broadcast addresses.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Cisco Press', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html', 'https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2832407&seqNum=6']

Question Text: ___________ is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision.
Choices:
a. CSMA/CA
b. TCP/UDP
c. TCP/IP
d. CSMA/CD
LLM Explanation: CSMA/CD, which stands for Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection, is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices send data at the same time, resulting in a collision. When a collision is detected, both devices stop transmitting, wait for a random time interval, and then retry to send the data again.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/5234-csma-cd.html']

Question Text: Ethernet standard ___________ BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling.
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet standard that defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling is 1000BASE-T. The '1000' in 1000BASE-T refers to the data transmission rate of 1000 Mbps or 1 Gbps. This standard uses Category 5 UTP or better cabling and 8P8C (RJ45) connectors.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'IEEE 802.3ab-1999 standard', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gigabit_Ethernet']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Preamble field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet frame allows devices to synchronize their receiver clocks. It consists of a 56-bit pattern of alternating 1s and 0s that enables the receiving devices to synchronize their receive clocks with the transmitter's clock, ensuring proper frame reception.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the ____________ IP address is in a different subnet than the host.
Choices:
a. Destination
b. Unicast
c. Broadcast
d. Source
LLM Explanation: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the destination IP address is in a different subnet than the host. When a host needs to communicate with another device on a different network, it forwards the packets to its default gateway, which then routes the packets to the appropriate network to reach the destination IP address.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 16: IP Routing Essentials)', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross (Chapter 4: The Network Layer)']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Application TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. Ethernet
c. TCP
d. IP
LLM Explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol in the TCP/IP model. It is used for sending and receiving email messages between servers. Ethernet is a data link layer protocol, while TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and IP (Internet Protocol) are transport layer and network layer protocols, respectively.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Transport TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. TCP
b. IP
c. Ethernet
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) resides in the Transport layer of the TCP/IP architecture. The Transport layer is responsible for providing end-to-end communication services for applications, including flow control, multiplexing, and reliability. TCP is a connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable data delivery between the source and destination hosts.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'Tanenbaum, A. S., & Wetherall, D. J. (2011). Computer Networks (5th Edition). Pearson.']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. IP
b. Ethernet
c. TCP
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: The Internet layer of the TCP/IP architecture is responsible for addressing, packaging, and routing functions. The primary protocol that resides in this layer is the Internet Protocol (IP). IP provides the logical addressing system and determines the path a packet must take based on the IP address. Ethernet operates at the lower link layer, while TCP and SMTP are higher-layer protocols that rely on IP.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by Kevin Fall, W. Richard Stevens']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Data Link & Physical TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: Ethernet resides in the Data Link and Physical layers of the TCP/IP architecture. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol, TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a transport layer protocol, and IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer protocol.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols is used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network?
Choices:
a. DNS
b. ARP
c. DHCP
d. ping
LLM Explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) is used by a device to learn the MAC address associated with an IP address on the same network. When a device needs to communicate with another device on the local network, it checks its ARP cache for the MAC address corresponding to the IP. If not found, it broadcasts an ARP request to all devices on the network asking 'Who has this IP address?'. The device with that IP responds with its MAC address, allowing communication to proceed.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 12: Analyzing Ethernet LAN Switching', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13718-5.html']

Question Text: If the devices below were connected with UTP Ethernet cables, which pairs of devices would require a straight-through cable? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Router and hub
b. Hub and switch
c. Switch and PC
d. Router and PC
LLM Explanation: A straight-through Ethernet cable is used when connecting devices of different types, such as a switch to a PC or a router to a PC. Switches, PCs, and routers are end devices, whereas a hub is a layer 1 device. When connecting a switch to a PC or a router directly to a PC, the transmit pins on one end must match the receive pins on the other end, requiring a straight-through cable. Hubs and switches are both intermediary devices, so connecting them would use a crossover cable instead.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/21223-cable-connection-21223.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. HTTP
b. SMTP
c. PPP
d. TCP
e. HTTPS
f. Ethernet
LLM Explanation: The data link layer protocols in the TCP/IP model are responsible for defining the format of data on the network medium and the protocols used to access it. Of the given choices, PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) and Ethernet are data link layer protocols. PPP is used for establishing a direct connection between two nodes over serial cable, phone line, trunk line, cellular telephone, specialized radio links, or fiber optic links. Ethernet is a family of wired technologies used in LANs, MANs and WANs. HTTP, HTTPS, SMTP are application layer protocols, while TCP is a transport layer protocol in the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Cisco Press', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols, W. Richard Stevens, Addison-Wesley', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_protocol_suite']

Question Text: Which of the following statements are functions of a routing protocol? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Learning routes and putting those routes into the routing table for routes advertised to the router by its neighboring routers
b. Forwarding IP packets based on a packetâ€™s destination IP address
c. Advertising known routes to neighboring routers
d. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router
LLM Explanation: The main functions of a routing protocol are to learn routes from neighboring routers and advertise known routes to those neighbors. The routing protocol puts the learned routes into the routing table. It does not handle packet forwarding based on destination IP (that's the job of the routing table lookup process) or learn routes for directly connected subnets (which are added to the routing table automatically when interfaces are configured).
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 16: Routing Protocol Concepts and Configuration', 'Cisco Press: Routing Protocols Companion Guide, Chapter 1: Routing Concepts']

Question Text: When you open a web browser and type in the hostname www.examsdigest.com, your computer does not send an IP packet with a destination IP address www.examsdigest.com; it sends an IP packet to an IP address used by the web server for Examsdigest. TCP/IP needs a way to let a computer find the IP address used by the listed hostname. That method uses the Domain Name System (DNS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. When you enter a hostname like www.examsdigest.com in a web browser, the computer does not directly send IP packets to that hostname. Instead, it first uses the Domain Name System (DNS) to resolve the hostname to its corresponding IP address. DNS is a distributed database that maps domain names to IP addresses. Once the IP address is obtained through DNS resolution, the computer then sends the IP packets to that resolved IP address, which is used by the web server hosting the website.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of IP Addressing and Routing', 'RFC 1035: Domain Names - Implementation and Specification', 'Cisco Press: Internetworking Fundamentals']

Question Text: A __________________ address is an address that enables transmission to every node in a local network.
Choices:
a. MAC
b. Broadcast
c. Unicast
d. Multicast
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to transmit data to every node on a local network segment. It allows a single packet to be sent to all devices on the network simultaneously. MAC addresses are unique identifiers for network interfaces, unicast addresses target a single specific recipient, and multicast addresses allow transmission to a subset of nodes, but not all nodes on a network.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 6: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: TCP and ______________ are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols.
Choices:
a. HTTP
b. UDP
c. DNS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is the correct answer. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP are the two most commonly used transport layer protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite. HTTP, DNS, and SMTP are application layer protocols that rely on TCP or UDP for transport.
URLs: ['TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James F. Kurose and Keith W. Ross', 'CISCO Press: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors?
Choices:
a. Start Frame Delimiter
b. Frame Check Sequence
c. Preamble
d. Data and Pad
LLM Explanation: The Frame Check Sequence (FCS) field in the Ethernet frame trailer provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine if the frame experienced transmission errors. The FCS contains a 4-byte cyclic redundancy check (CRC) value calculated by the sending device. The receiving device recalculates the CRC and compares it to the value in the FCS field. If they match, the frame is considered valid. If they differ, the frame contained errors and is discarded.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet']
